Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Environmental Quality and the Costs of Reproduction: an Experimental Test in a Cooperatively Breeding Bird
Award.AbstractNarration:
Organisms are faced with a fundamental decision: to invest valuable resources and energy in reproduction or in their own survival. As a result, reproduction may lead to lowered survival, a relationship called the "cost of reproduction." For some organisms, the cost of reproduction is thought to be so high that parents cannot reproduce without additional help. Ultimately, this may be why some species live in complex family groups, or cooperatively breeding societies, where individuals form social groups to raise others' offspring. Finding food for the young is difficult, but if individuals come together to find food the cost of reproduction is lowered. The researchers are studying cooperatively breeding birds to determine whether the cost of reproduction promotes rearing young in family groups. This project specifically explores how resources available during reproduction can increase or decrease the cost of reproduction and alter group dynamics. This research will also create two positions for local Kenyan field assistants, and provide mentoring to a female undergraduate student who will assist with data collection and pursue an independent project. Results will be shared with US and Kenyan undergraduate students as part of a semester abroad in Tropical Biology. This research will also be shared with Kenyan students from rural elementary schools through participation in the grassroots Laikipia Conservation Clubs.

Researchers will manipulate territory quality through an insect supplementation at nests of a cooperatively breeding species, the superb starling (Lamprotornis superbus), to examine whether environmental conditions drive the cost of reproduction. Birds will be caught both before and during chick rearing to look at the physiological changes that occur as a result of reproduction. Previous research in this system has indicated that oxidative stress increases with greater chick-rearing effort, a strong candidate measure that may link reproductive effort to reduced survival. The researchers will examine how food supplementation alters the magnitude of these physiological changes to infer how resource availability drives the cost of reproduction. Samples and data will be stored at Columbia and made publically available post publication through Dryad, a public data repository for evolutionary and ecological data.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Organisms are faced with a fundamental decision: to invest valuable resources and energy in reproduction or in their own survival. As a result, reproduction leads to reduced survival, a relationship called the ‘cost of reproduction’. For some organisms, the cost of reproduction is thought to be so high that parents cannot reproduce without additional help. Finding food for the young is difficult, but if individuals come together to find food this cost of reproduction can be lowered. The researchers studied reproduction in a bird that breeds cooperatively in social groups to determine whether the cost of reproduction promotes rearing young in larger groups. This project specifically explored how resources available during reproduction (e.g. food shaped by rainfall levels) can increase or decrease the cost of reproduction and alter group dynamics for mothers, fathers, and non-breeding individuals called helpers. Results from this project revealed that some birds caring for young in larger groups do reduce the work they invest in rearing nestlings, which would promote their future survival. However, this was only the case for mothers and fathers, whereas helpers at the nest actually increased the amount of care they performed when in a larger group. Furthermore, fathers only benefited from having a larger group of helpers at their nest (via reducing the nestling care they performed) during wetter breeding seasons relative to drier seasons of below average rainfall. These results show that environmental conditions do shape the costs of reproduction, though helpers at the nest are most beneficial in years where conditions are favorable rather than when they are poor. This research also showed that individuals paid very little physiological cost of caring for young, as birds adjusted their investment in offspring care according to their physiological condition prior to breeding. In other words, individuals in better condition provided more offspring care whereas those in poorer condition provided little to no care. Breeding cooperatively in unpredictable environments therefore enables individuals to reduce their cost of reproduction because they gain flexibility in how much offspring care they perform—birds can adjust their nestlings provisioning behavior both according to their physiological condition, as well as to the number of helpers at the nest also caring for young. Thus, increased flexibility in offspring care behavior may represent an important benefit that shapes the evolution of cooperative breeding.

 

This research benefited the local Kenyan communities surrounding our research site by creating three field assistant positions, which included a salary, housing, and benefits. This grant also created a variety of student mentorship opportunities, including laboratory-based projects for a US high school student and an MA student, as well as a field-based internship for a female undergraduate student who moved on to a PhD position where she now applies the bird handling and observation skills she gained during this project. Results from this project were also shared with a variety of audiences, including academics at international conferences, the local communities where the researchers spoke to Kenyan primary and high school students, and the general public via radio interviews and popular articles. This award resulted in two manuscripts that are currently under review, with an additional manuscript currently in preparation for submission.
